Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Starting with the input data, each line has a timestamp, action type, application name, window title (for some actions), and sometimes additional attributes like Keys or Action. The goal is to group these into cases based on the user's workflow. First, I'll look for patterns in the sequence of actions. Let's go through each entry:

Name: Inductive Reasoning - IND
Text: After the first two lines (both FOCUS on Word but different windows), there's a TYPING on Document1.docx. Wait, but the second line's FOCUS was on Document1.docx, so maybe the TYPING follows from that. Then SAVE, then SWITCH to Chrome. So perhaps the user started with Quarterly_Report (Case 1), then switched to Document1 (maybe via closing and reopening?), work on it, save, switch to Chrome.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Alternatively, perhaps the first two FOCUS events are separate cases. Let's see: Case 1: Starts with FOCUS on Quarterly_Report (08:59:50). Then, perhaps the user closed it (no CLOSE event listed, so maybe they just closed it implicitly?), then opened Document1 again at 09:00 with FOCUS. But since there's no CLOSE event, maybe the user just kept it open.

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: Alternatively, maybe the first two FOCUS events are part of the same case because they're both in the same process instance. The user might have started with Quarterly_Report, then closed it (not logged) and reopened Document1, so the FOCUS on Document1 is part of the same case. That could make sense. Let's tentatively consider that as Case 1, which includes both documents?

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: This suggests that the main workflow is: start with Quarterly_Report (Case 1), then switch to Document1 (maybe via closing and reopening?), work on it, save, switch to Chrome, handle emails, then switch to Acrobat for report editing, then go back to Excel, interact with it, save, switch back to Word, and close. But the initial FOCUS on Quarterly_Report is followed by a FOCUS on Document1.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Each case should have a start and end, with events in between. The case ID can be generated sequentially, like Case_001, Case_002, etc., but based on the analysis, it might be a single case. Now, to structure the event log: Each event will have: Case ID: Case_001 Activity Name: e.g., FOCUS, TYPING, SAVE, SWITCH, etc. Timestamp Additional attributes like Application, Window, Action (if applicable), Keys, etc.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Now, checking if all original entries are included: Original entries: 1. 08:59:50 FOCUS Event1 2. 09:00 FOCUS Event2 ... This covers all original events. The activities are grouped into a single case because the user's actions form a continuous workflow without distinct session breaks except for the final close.
